steps.title: AVERAGE Function
steps.content:
Using AVERAGE in Excel

For this set of activities, you will need the Sports Day Fundraiser file.

This can be found in the ADVANCED FUNCTIONS section under the Excel Skills page on Aidan's Central.

The AVERAGE function calculates the arithmetic mean of a range of numbers.

Example:

=AVERAGE(H2:H21)

This calculates the average donation from the range H2:H21

Create a New Worksheet

First, create a new sheet named 'Average Analysis' to store your results.

Exercise 1: Calculate Average Donation
  1. In cell H22, create the formula =AVERAGE(H2:H21) to calculate the average donation
  2. In your 'Average Analysis' sheet, create a summary with 'Average Donation' in A1 and copy the result from H22 into B1

quiz.question: If you have donation amounts of $5, $10, $0, $15, and $20, what will =AVERAGE(H2:H6) return?

steps.title: COUNTIF Function
steps.content:
Counting with Conditions

The COUNTIF function helps analyse how many entries match specific criteria.

Formula Examples:

=COUNTIF(E2:E21, "L")

Count Large T-shirts

=COUNTIF(G2:G21, ">4")

Count large group bookings

=COUNTIF(I2:I21, "Yes")

Count newsletter subscribers

Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'COUNTIF Analysis' to store your counting results.

Exercise 1: Count T-shirt Sizes

Let's analyse T-shirt size distribution:

  1. In your 'COUNTIF Analysis' sheet, add headers 'T-shirt Size' in A1 and 'Count' in B1
  2. Enter S, M, L in cells A2:A4
  3. In B2, create the formula =COUNTIF('Sheet1'!E2:E21, "S") and copy down, changing "S" to "M" and "L" for the other sizes
Exercise 2: Count High-Value Donations

Now let's count donations above certain thresholds:

  1. In A6, type 'Donations Over $10' and create the formula =COUNTIF('Sheet1'!H2:H21, ">10") in B6
  2. In A7, type 'Newsletter Subscribers' and create the formula =COUNTIF('Sheet1'!I2:I21, "Yes") in B7

Common Criteria Operators:

  • ">100" Greater than
  • "<50" Less than
  • ">=20" Greater or equal
  • "=Text" Exact match
  • "*text*" Contains text
  • "<>No" Not equal to

quiz.question: To count how many people donated more than $20, which formula would you use?

steps.title: IF Function
steps.content:
Making Decisions with IF

The IF function performs logical tests and returns different values based on whether the test is TRUE or FALSE.

Formula Examples:

=IF(G2>3, "Large Group", "Small Group")

Classify group sizes based on attendance

=IF(H2>15, "High Donor", "Regular Donor")

Categorise donors based on donation amount

Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'IF Analysis' to practice logical functions.

Exercise 1: Categorise Group Sizes

Let's categorise participants by their group booking size:

  1. Set up headers in your 'IF Analysis' sheet: 'Name' (A1), 'Seats Booked' (B1), 'Group Size Category' (C1)
  2. Copy participant names and seat booking data from the main sheet into columns A and B
  3. In C2, create the formula =IF(B2>4, "Large Group", "Small Group") and copy down to C21
Exercise 2: Identify High-Value Donors

Now let's identify participants who made significant donations:

  1. Add headers 'Donor Category' (D1) and 'Donation Amount' (E1), then copy donation data from the main sheet into column E
  2. In D2, create the formula =IF(E2>10, "High Donor", "Regular Donor") and copy down to D21
  3. Create a summary count in G1 ('High Donors Count') and use COUNTIF in H1 to count "High Donor" entries

quiz.question: What will =IF(H2>10, "Thank You", "Welcome") return for a $15 donation?

steps.title: Conditional Formatting
steps.content:
Visualising Fundraiser Data

Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'Formatting Practice' to apply conditional formatting rules.

Exercise 1: Format Donation Amounts

Let's apply conditional formatting to highlight different donation levels:

  1. Copy all fundraiser data to your 'Formatting Practice' sheet (headers A1:I1 and data A2:I21)
  2. Select donation range H2:H21, go to Home → Conditional Formatting → Highlight Cells Rules → Greater Than, enter 15 and choose green fill
  3. Apply another rule for donations less than 5 with red fill
Exercise 2: Format Group Booking Sizes

Now let's format the seat booking column to show capacity visually:

  1. Select range G2:G21, go to Conditional Formatting → Data Bars → Gradient Fill → Blue Data Bar
  2. For additional visual clarity, add an icon set: select the same range, go to Conditional Formatting → Icon Sets → 3 Traffic Lights

Step-by-Step Guide:

  1. Select your data range (e.g., H2:H21 for donations)
  2. Go to the Home tab in the Excel ribbon
  3. Click the Conditional Formatting button
  5. Choose your rule type:
    • Highlight Cells Rules → Greater Than → Enter $20 for high donations
    • Color Scales → Red-Yellow-Green for booking distributions
    • Data Bars → Gradient Fill for visual donation comparisons
  6. Customise your format styles in the dialog box

Recommended Rules for Our Dataset:

Donations

  • Green for >$20
  • Yellow for $10-$20
  • Red for <$10

Group Sizes

  • Data bars for visual comparison
  • Icon sets for capacity warnings
Self-Assessment Checklist

Before finishing, ensure you have completed:

  • ✅ Created 'Average Analysis' sheet with average donation calculation
  • ✅ Created 'COUNTIF Analysis' sheet with T-shirt size counts and donor categories
  • ✅ Created 'IF Analysis' sheet with group size and donor categorisation
  • ✅ Created 'Formatting Practice' sheet with conditional formatting applied
  • ✅ Applied at least 3 different conditional formatting rules
  • ✅ Tested all formulas work correctly with the sample data

quiz.question: Which formatting would best show the distribution of seat bookings from smallest to largest?
